thread.title: Trevor O'Hoy's excellent Mongolian adventure comes to an end
thread.title_full: Trevor O'Hoy's excellent Mongolian adventure comes to an end

author: Simon Evans
title: Trevor O'Hoy's excellent Mongolian adventure comes to an end
text:
The wild and woolly ways of doing business and concerns about corporate governance have prompted former Foster's Group chief executive Trevor O'Hoy to resign as a director of Mongolia's largest alcohol group APU after three years.
Closer to home, he's predicting the trends hurting mainstream brewers such as the firm he used to run will accelerate.
People are drinking less and they're drinking better.
Trevor O'Hoy Mr O'Hoy became a director of APU, which makes the leading beer and vodka brands in Mongolia, in April 2012, but has bowed out after three years on the board, after becoming increasingly concerned at the levels of corporate governance in the country.
"I wasn't comfortable with it. It's a real pity," he said.
Mr O'Hoy also said he had some misgivings about APU's corporate strategy as it started expanding into dairy products.
But one area where he has the utmost confidence is the craft beer market, which continues to accelerate and is causing serious headaches for the company he used to run. Foster's Group, which makes Victoria Bitter and Carlton Draught, was acquired in 2011 for $11 billion by SABMiller, which along with Japanese firm Kirin's Lion beer business is battling a mainstream beer market which is shrinking as drinkers turn more toward premium and craft beers.
Mr O'Hoy has a small shareholding in Byron Bay-based craft brewer Stone & Wood, where he is also a director, and says it is thriving as the craft beer market booms.
"People are drinking less and they're drinking better," he says.
He says Stone & Wood has been able to lift both sales revenue and profits by more than 100 per cent over each of the past three years. The broader craft beer market would continue to grow at a rate of more than 10 to 15 per cent.
"It's a real issue for the big commercial brewers," he says. "There's been a huge shift under way and it's getting faster."
Mr O'Hoy, who was chief executive of Foster's from 2004 to 2008, says consumer confidence in Australia seems to be subdued. "It's very fragile," he says.
Taking the healthy option But parts of the market, such as health and well-being, are still strong since people are prepared to spend money on their health and fitness.
Mr O'Hoy is executive chairman in Australia of vitamins group Swisse Wellness and says there is solid momentum in the business. One of the over-arching trends driving sales in the vitamins market at a retail level is large volumes of vitamins being purchased by Chinese expatriates in Australia, who send them to relatives and friends in China.
"People in the vitamins space have been the beneficiaries of it."
This has come about because of a lack of confidence in the quality and manufacturing practices of some China-based health food and vitamin supplement makers. Some people in China prefer the vitamins made by companies in the Western world. Those perceptions had been fuelled in part by scandals involving contaminated milk powder in China.
ASX-listed Blackmores, one of Australia's biggest vitamin and natural health foods groups, has experienced an extraordinary rise in its share price in the past 12 months from $27 to $87, giving it a market capitalisation of $1.5 billion. Analysts have pointed to Chinese expatriates' buying vitamins in Australia as a major reason.
Swisse has recruited a number of Australian sporting stars and celebrities to front its marketing campaigns including former Test cricket captain Ricky Ponting, actor Nicole Kidman, and restaurant owner and judge on Network Ten's Master Chef program, George Calombaris.
